values.comments:
This course is a continuation of CHEM 053. Students are introduced to modern
laboratory techniques and participate in experimental activities that promote the
development of basic and advanced science process skills. This course focuses on
understanding and analyzing substances and reactions and investigating chemical
interactions. Aspects of qualitative and quantitative analysis, determination of chemical
and physical properties, and chemical synthesis are covered.
Most students felt that this class was uninteresting and that there was too much
work involved for a .5 credit course. A majority also thought that the practical and
written exams were too difficult and that they covered concepts that were not heavily
discussed in lab or lecture. Some students also felt that this class had a lack of
organization.
Overall, students said that Professor Maeyer was “a great instructor.” She
planned interesting demonstrations for every lecture that complemented the labs. They
were pleased that she was very accessible and answered questions in lecture that helped
with the weekly lab reports. Professor Maeyer would also extend report deadlines and
move around exam dates if her course exam conflicted with the CHEM 102 exams.
The prerequisite for this class is CHEM 053. It is often taken in conjunction of
CHEM 102. This class is recommended for freshman, but they should be prepared for a
“serious time commitment.”
